news-item.title: Danone rises on high volatility
news-item.text:
Danone (FR:BN), France's largest food producer company by market capitalisation, traded between an intraday low of EUR49.06 and a high of EUR49.92. The price range has expanded in the last two days (from 72.0c two days ago to 85.50c today) which, accompanied by a price rise, is a bullish signal. The average daily volatility of 1.6% places the stock in the 3rd quartile in the market meaning it is mildly volatile. Today its volatility (highest price minus lowest price/lowest price) of 1.7% was 1.7 times the average daily volatility of 1.6%, up from 1.3% on Thursday and 1.5% on Wednesday. A price rise on high volatility is a bullish signal. The stock price increased 38.50c (or 0.8%) to close at EUR49.87, ending a five-day streak of losses. Compared with the CAC 40 Index which fell 27.0 points (or 0.6%) in the day, this represented a relative price increase of 1.4%. To download our Detailed Research Report (PDF), giving comprehensive trading and background information on Danone, please click http://www.buysellsignals.com/001051811940314211 Bullish SignalsOversold/Bullish/Support Signals- The Stochastic indicator of 14.6 has pierced the oversold line of 20. Bearish Signals- The price decreased 1.3% in the last week and 0.9% in the last month. - In the last three months the stock has hit a new 52-week low four times, pointing to a downtrend. - The 2.8% premium to 12-month low of EUR48.50 against the 17.5% discount to high of EUR60.45 suggests the stock continues to push for new lows. - The present value of EUR1,000 (PV1000) invested one year ago in Danone is EUR898, for a capital loss of EUR102.
NoteBeta: the Beta of Danone stock is 0.3. A Beta lower than 1 suggests this is a low risk, low return stock with volatility less than that of the market.
